Description: Rim and body sherd of Chian pottery Type B1 kantharos; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, streaky black (fired red) below; lotus flower in added white outline and other traces; two white bands below; exterior: reserved; inscription on exterior.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Site 51 (Hogarth), an ‘early chamber’ in the area of the Aphrodite sanctuary and Scarab Factory (Hogarth 1898-9, 41; Edgar 1898-9, 50) (close to)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

'Naukratis 1899' is marked in ink on the interior surface. Kantharoi Type B1 have lotus flowers and lotus buds on the interior (Williams 1983, 169). Many kantharoi Type B have painted inscriptions beneath the rim and several have been found on Aegina as well as at Naukratis. Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983 One of four fragments of inscribed ceramic cited by Edgar, BSA 1898-9,50, pl. 4, no 26 as having been found with scarab moulds and being proof that the material was secondary rubbish and not contemporary.
Bibliographic references: Cook & Woodhead 1952 / Painted Inscriptions on Chiot Pottery (p. 170, no. 221)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (pl. IV, no. 26)
Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 697, no. 548)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1883) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
